_exec_summary.SummaryText:
To:     EPA * Risk Management Program * Submit 2004
From:      Farmer Cooperative Co. Bruce Buxton General Manager
Re:     RMP-Executive Summary
Date:     06/10/2004


Accidental Release Prevention / Emergency Response Plan 
 Farmers Cooperative Company Readlyn Iowa

This facility complies with ANSI Standard K-61.1-1995 requirements for Anhydrous Ammonia storage. Farmers Cooperative Company owns this fertilizer facility, and it is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state and local laws. If an emergency were to occur, it is our policy to immediately notify the Readlyn Fire Department (with a 911 call) and request that it respond to the emergency. Incidental to the notification to the fire department, a call to the Bremer County, Iowa LEPC will be made. 

While we have planned for an emergency, it is acknowledged that a real emergency will be unexpected and may very well be much different and cannot be ensured to duplicate what may have been planned. In reality, the situation that develops may not happen in the manner in which it has been planned. In that event, what has been planned will serve only as a guideline to follow.

The Emergency Action Plan for this facility describes certain procedures that are intended to minimize the hazards associated with human health and the environment from fires, explosions, the sudden and unexpected release of chemicals (i.e. anhydrous ammonia), tornadoes, bomb threats or other accidents or acts of God which might occur on our premises. 

The primary emergency coordinator for Readlyn, Iowa location is Bruce Buxton, general manager, Roger Buhr ,Location Manager and Randy Wurzer, agronomy manager. Their work phone, 24 hr. phone and cell phone numbers are provided in the registration section of this document. 
In addition, the following individuals (with associated work and 24hr. emergency response telephone numbers) are to be contacted in order:

Name:        Work Number:    24 hr. Number:     cell Number:
Bruce Buxton    319-279-3396    319

-352-5899    319-240-4261
Roger Buhr        319-279-3396    319-279-3661    319-939-1945
Randy Wurzer    319-279-3396    563-237-6372    319-404-1065

Description of the Anhydrous Ammonia Storage/Distribution Plant and the Regulated substance handled at Farmers Cooperative Company, Readlyn, Iowa Zip 50668:

The facility is a bulk anhydrous ammonia storage and distribution plant. The anhydrous ammonia that is stored at this facility is distributed to agricultural corn producers in the surrounding area who utilize anhydrous ammonia as a crop nutrient.

The storage plant consists of one (1) 30,000 gallon storage tank with associated piping, valves, liquid pumps and thirty-seven(37) 1,000 gallon anhydrous  ammonia delivery wagons. The plant is serviced by Semi-Trailer trucks which would be 8,000 gal. (85% level would be 34,700 lbs).
So the plant total maximum amount of anhydrous ammonia at this facility:

Type of Storage Tank            Amount of anhydrous ammonia        
Bulk Storage Tank (30,000gal)            130,000 pounds
37 Nurse Tank Wagons (1000 gal)        160,500 pounds
Semi-Trailer Truck (8,000 gal)              34,700 pounds
Maximum amount that could be at Plant    325,200 pounds


The plant has 4 anhydrous ammonia risers to load wagons; all four riser stations have stainless steel TriPod safety couplers (model #5-1130550 TP-6 1? 77GPM tripod) for pull away protection.    The anhydrous ammonia plant is only operated on a seasonal basis (spring and late fall). At maximum, the plant operates a total of three months a year. 

The Worst-Case and Alternatives Release Scenario:
The worst ?case scenario is failure of the 30,000 gallon storage tank when filled to the greatest amount allowed (85% of capacity), resulting in the release of the total volume in a gaseous (hazardous ammonia vapor cloud) form. According to EPA?s RMP Computer Program, the distance to the endpoint is 4.4 miles. 
The town of Readlyn which includes schools, residence, public recreational areas, and business are all within the distance to the endpoint, with a

total population of 957. 

The alternative release scenario involves the transport delivery vehicle pulling away from the intake lines into the storage plant without disconnecting the transfer hoses. The resulting release, according to the EPA?s RMP Computer Program has a distance to endpoint of 0.1 mile.

Since this facility is located in a relatively close proximity to the town of Readlyn, provisions have been designed to notify all affected persons and evacuate the area using the local police and firemen?s force.
General Accidental release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:

This facility complies with EPA?s  accident prevention rule and all applicable state and local codes and regulations. The anhydrous ammonia system is designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with ANSI StandardK-61.1 1995 and State law.

Accident History:
Farmers Cooperative Company has never had an accident involving ammonia that caused death, permanent injury, property or environmental damage, or evacuations. 

Emergency Response Program:

In the event of an emergency involving our anhydrous ammonia plant, it is our policy to notify the Readlyn Fire Department and request that they respond to the emergency. (We have two volunteer firemen who work here at the Cooperative.) They would in turn call the Haz-Mat team in Waterloo. We have visited with the fire department about this policy. 

Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

The plan is to minimize those hazards to human health and to the environment that are associated with accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. Employees working at the bulk storage plant make routine observations prior to and during transfer operations of the anhydrous ammonia from the storage vessel to nurse tanks. In so doing, they are able to detect any problems that should be fixed. 
This routine inspection helps identifies any portion of the system which may be under stress or about to fail. Repairs can be made before they become a pro

blem. In addition the Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship performs regular inspection of this facility. Employees are trained annually to recognize the hazards associated with storage handling of anhydrous ammonia. In addition to annual training for employees who have been on the job for a number of years, the company conducts training for new hires. This training includes classroom instruction and a written test. It is our policy to start a new hire with and order employee in the beginning. It is our policy to replace all safety relief valves, fittings, and hoses in accordance with the law. The Farmers Cooperative Company maintains a written log that shows a record of any maintenance performed on all anhydrous ammonia equipment.
